user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName(osal_id_t *timer_id, const char *timebase_name)
{
    int32          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t objtype;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(timebase_name);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, timebase_name, timer_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_APINAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_API_NAME,OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the provided function and related symbols for use of compiler-specific language extensions. No suspicious fragments were found. Specifically:

- There are no occurrences of compiler-extension keywords or builtins such as __attribute__, __extension__, __builtin_*, __asm, __typeof__, statement-expression GCC ({ ... }), nested functions, label-as-value (&&label), or other non-standard GCC/Clang/MSVC keywords.
- No use of inline assembly or pragmas that are compiler-specific (e.g., #pragma GCC, #pragma pack) appears in the shown code.
- The use of `static inline` is standard C (C99 and later) and not a compiler extension by itself.
- The pthreads call (pthread_getspecific) and the cppcheck comment are library/analysis items, not compiler language extensions.
- Macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_APINAME, ARGCHECK, LENGTHCHECK) expand to checks but their visible definitions do not reveal any compiler-extension constructs; there is no evidence in the provided expansions that they rely on compiler-specific features.
- Union-based value access (OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t usage) and bit-shifting/typedefs are standard C, not extensions.

If there are other macro definitions (e.g., BUGCHECK, OS_ObjectIdToInteger, OS_ObjectIdGetByName) or portions of the codebase that were not provided and that use compiler-specific builtins or attributes, those should be submitted for review. Based on the code fragments shown, there are no explicit compiler language extensions to report under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
